Key Arguments: The bill allows the government to determine 'truth', which is problematic in a pluralistic society.
Truth should emerge from free and open debate, not be enforced by authorities.
The natural evolution of knowledge means what is considered misinformation today could be accepted truth tomorrow.
Censorship stifles scientific and societal progress.
The bill could be abused due to human biases and the tendency to demonize opposing views.
The subjective nature of 'harm' could lead to misuse of the bill to suppress legitimate debate.
The bill could create a chilling effect on free speech and diversity of opinions.
The qualifications of those enforcing the bill to determine harm are questionable.
Notable Quotes: Misinformation and Disinformation can only be deemed to occur after some 'truth' has been 'decided'.
Science has only truly flourished where people are free to question accepted 'ways of thinking'.
You can be unhinged and still be right.
The claim of misinformation/disinformation 'causing harm' could easily be weaponised by powerful lobby groups to shut down legitimate debate.
